Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: A cruising aircraft simply requests the routine altimeter setting.
Story: I was just about to take a sip of my lukewarm coffee when my phone buzzed. It was Jamie, an old classmate who’d recently moved to town. “Hey! Any good restaurant recommendations nearby?” the message read. I knew Jamie didn’t know many people here yet, and I felt a tug of responsibility to help, to be friendly and welcoming. But as I started typing a reply, the headset crackled in my ear. “Center, this is Delta 452, request current altimeter setting.” My eyes darted to the radar screen. I was on shift, and every second counted. The pilots depended on me for precise, immediate information. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between sending Jamie a thoughtful reply and keying in the altimeter setting for Delta 452. I could feel the pressure mounting—on one side, the simple but important expectation to be a helpful acquaintance; on the other, the critical, time-sensitive demands of my job. My heart thudded as I hesitated, caught between two worlds, knowing I couldn’t let either down.
